awd_titl_txt: The Dynamics of Thin Current Sheets and the Triggering of Fast Reconnection in Different Plasma Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
This research aims to understand the triggering mechanism for some of the most energetic events and beautiful light shows in the visible universe. Space and astrophysical plasmas - the ionized gases constituting the greatest part of the visible (baryonic) Universe - are responsible for a variety of observed energetic phenomena from pulsar gamma-ray flares, to solar flares, to magnetospheric substorms leading to Aurora Borealis.  All of these processes are characterized by a preliminary phase of energy storage, where magnetic field energy is built up due to rotational, gravitational, or convective motions of the plasma, followed by the sudden triggering of rapid energy release. Magnetic reconnection, the splicing and reforming of magnetic field lines is thought to be at the heart of most observed explosive phenomena.  The results of this research will allow a better understanding of the transition from stability to the sudden release of magnetic energy, with the ability to predict the critical parameters necessary for the transition in different astrophysical, as well as laboratory plasmas. This research project?s broader impact includes a more advanced understanding of this decades-old plasma physics problem both in laboratory and astrophysical contexts, with applications involving future laboratory experiments and advanced numerical computations, as well as NASA missions.

The classic picture of magnetic reconnection involves current sheets, assumed to be planar-like and concentrated very narrowly in the third dimension. Recently, the slow, stationary reconnection scenario was transformed by the discovery that such configuration is unstable to tearing at large values of the Lundquist number, S, leading to one promising picture (a.k.a. the plasmoid instability) of fast reconnection.  The plasmoid instability of the planar current sheet has a paradoxical feature, in that the instability growth rate diverges with S. Growth rates which become arbitrarily large at high S therefore beg the question of how a system transitions from stability to instability. This difficulty with diverging growth rates was resolved recently by Pucci and Velli, who showed that a limiting current sheet inverse aspect ratio separates slow and fast reconnecting modes, a property they called "Ideal Tearing", or IT. As a consequence, fast reconnection sets in in relatively thick current sheets and all plasmoid instability scalings (number of islands etc.) require correction. Such a scenario is promising in that it not only can explain observed fast reconnection rates, but might also account for the reconnection trigger mechanism. The present research program builds on the IT reconnection framework and generalizes it to different plasma configurations in different regimes by: 1) extending the linear scaling theory to more general equilibria and two dimensions including flows and kinetic regimes; 2) simulating collapsing current sheet in 3D resistive MHD to study nonlinear evolution in configurations with and without initial flows. The results will impact the understanding of catastrophic energy release in natural and laboratory plasmas.

por.por_cntn:
Magnetic reconnection is thought to be the mechanism underlying many explosive phenomena observed in both space and laboratory plasmas, ranging from disruptive processes in fusion devices, the sawtooth crashes observed in tokamaks, to magnetospheric substorms, solar flares - coronal mass ejections in the heliosphere, and even gamma-ray flares from pulsars. “The Dynamics of Thin Current Sheets and the Triggering of Fast Reconnection in Different Plasma Environments” was devoted to understanding the reconnection process, both of the initiation of linear instability in different plasma regimes and geometries as well as the subsequequent nonlinear evolution.

The classic picture of reconnection involves current sheets, extended over a quasi-2D surface, assumed to be planar-like and concentrated very narrowly in the third dimension. Slow, stationary reconnection scenarios that could not explain flares were transformed by the discovery that such configurations always become unstable to tearing instabilities in the limit of large conductivities. The fact that growth rates become arbitrarily large placed limits on configurations that can occur in nature before what our group termed "Ideal Tearing" sets in.

Through this project, the generalized ``Ideal" instability criterion for arbitrary magnetic field equilibrium profiles  was found and published. At the same time, a generalized study of the linear and nonlinear evolution of Ideal Tearing including the Hall effect  was carried out. With a funded PhD student,  Chen Shi,  we demonstrated how and why different critical values for the electrical conductivity have been found in different numerical simulations and explained why the transition occurs at values between a few thousand and ~ ten thousand of the magnetic Reynolds number.

Our group discovered how the Hall effect enters at a certain point of the self-similar 2D cascade, changing the localization of plasmoid formation and introducing oscillatory behaviour in the collapse. The 2.5D Hall-MHD simulations (to study the transition from resistive-MHD reconnection to Hall reconnection) showed that as the ion inertial length increases from 0 to become greater than the thickness of the inner, singular layer of the ideal tearing mode, the evolution and the structure of the current sheet change significantly. When the ion inertial length is sufficiently small, the reconnection is purely plasmoid-dominant, consistent with the recursive reconnection picture we generalized. When the inertial length is larger than the singular layer thickness, reconnection evolves into the Hall-dominant regime soon after tearing occurs in the original sheet: a single X-point with a wide, opened up exhaust is creates. When the ion-inertial length and singular layer thicknees are comparable, an intermediate state is observed: an X-point collapsing into a finite length new sheet forms and plasmoids continue to be generated and ejected out from the X-point.

In a separate effort, we compared the different fractal reconnection scenarios that have been proposed, and derived generalized scaling relations for the recursive triggering of fast, “ideal” —i.e., Lundquist number independent—tearing in collapsing current sheet configurations with arbitrary current profile shapes. An important result was that the Sweet–Parker scaling with Lundquist number, if interpreted as the aspect ratio of the singular layer in an ideally unstable sheet, is universal and does not depend on the details of the current profile in the sheet. Such a scaling, however, must not be interpreted in terms of stationary reconnection, rather it defines a step in the accelerating sequence of events of the ideal tearing mediated fractal cascade. We calculated scalings for the expected number of plasmoids for such generic profiles and realistic Lundquist numbers, showing that in ideal tearing scenarios a smaller number of plasmoids, by orders of magnitude, are formed compared to the original fractal model. During the no-cost extension, the Hall 3D lnear analysis was completed as well as the extension of the IT instability studies to partially ionized plasmas.

Our research sparked considerable research from competing teams, and we can truly argue that we opened whole new paths of research that other groups have moved on developing. One specific topic being the effects of Ideal Tearing on the non-linear MHD cascade: however, such papers have not completeley incorporated the lesson of the ideal nature of the instability, and therefore this new avenue of research remains fertiie:  the competition of current sheet formation and instability on the development of MHD turbulence inertial range spectra and particle acceleration.

Through this project Chen Shi, has been brought into the fold of contemporary magnetic reconnection research, and is now a capable researcher who has modified MHD codes and developed his own algorithms. Chen graduated in the summer of 2020, is presently a post-doc at UCLA and is developing into an outstanding plasma physics researcher. Another collaborator, Anna Tenerani, has furthered her career transitioning from a post-doc and research scientist at UCLA to an assistant professor in the plasma physics group at U Texas, Austin.
